original_data.question: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of itchy, watery eyes for the past week. He has also been sneezing multiple times a day during this period. He had a similar episode 1 year ago around springtime. He has iron deficiency anemia and ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include ferrous sulfate, artificial tear drops, and indomethacin. He works as an elementary school teacher. His vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/20 without correction. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge. The pupils are 3 mm, equal, and reactive to light. Examination of the anterior chamber of the eye is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

model_response:
The patient has seasonal allergic conjunctivitis. The treatment is usually symptomatic. Erythromycin ointment is used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis. Ketotifen eye drops are used to treat seasonal allergic conjunctivitis. Warm compresses are used to treat eyelid disorders. Fluorometholone eye drops are used to treat inflammatory conditions of the eye.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>
